Package moulton.scalable.containers

Class Panel

  • java.lang.Object
    • moulton.scalable.utils.MenuComponent
      • moulton.scalable.containers.Panel
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    PanelPlus, PartitionPanel
    public class Panel
extends MenuComponent
    A panel to serve as a parent component and backdrop for other MenuComponents. When you want to add a menu component to this, simply call the component's constructor, which will either call addToGrid(MenuComponent, int, int) if the component is to reside in a gridded fashion, or will add itself to this Panel's comps.

    One can use the createRoot(Color) method to create a simple menu panel. For any panel, setColor(Color) can be used to set its backdrop color. Other methods like setOutline(boolean), and setTextResize(Boolean) can further be used to customize the Panel. The GridFormatter (saved as grid) is in charge of formatting the details of the grid, such as margin, frame, and column or row weights.

    Author:
    Matthew Moulton

        The string expressions to define the dimensions of this panel on its parent panel.

      • color

        protected java.awt.Color color
        The background color of this panel. A rectangle filled with this color is rendered unless it is null.
        See Also:
        setColor(Color), getColor()

      • outline

        protected boolean outline
        Whether or not this panel should draw a black outline on its border.
        See Also:
        setOutline(boolean), getOutline()

      • comps

        protected java.util.LinkedList<MenuComponent> comps
        A list of the components held in free-form. The coordinates of the components held here are found by using this panel's coordinates at render time and then solving the algebraic expressions in the component that defines its location.

      • grid

        protected GridFormatter grid

      • lastHeight

        protected int lastHeight
        The height of the panel (in pixels) at last render. Used by MenuComponent to know how much the text should resize for child components. Also used to tell child components their maximum heights

      • lastWidth

        protected int lastWidth
        The width of the panel (in pixels) at last render. Used to tell child components their maximum widths

    • Method Detail

      • createRoot

        public static Panel createRoot​(java.awt.Color background)
        Creates a root panel. This is the same as calling Panel(Panel, int, int, Color) with null, 0, 0, and background respectively but sometimes that can look confusing. For readability, this can be used. For the menu to be usable, the root panel must be saved as MenuManager.menu.
        Parameters:
        background - the background color
        Returns:
        the created root panel

      • render

        public void render​(java.awt.Graphics g,
                   int xx,
                   int yy,
                   int ww,
                   int hh)
        Description copied from class: MenuComponent
        Draws on the graphics object to represent this component visually. When this method is called, the type of panel storing (grid or free) has been taken into account and the dimensions of the space given to this component have been calculated using MenuComponent.solveString(String, int, int).
        Specified by:
        render in class MenuComponent
        Parameters:
        g - the graphics object to draw on
        xx - the x-position on the graphics image that this component's alloted space begins
        yy - the y-position on the graphics image that this component's alloted space begins
        ww - the width on the graphics image that this component is given
        hh - the height on the graphics image this component is given

      • getRenderOffset

        public int[] getRenderOffset​(MenuComponent comp)
        Although Panel tells its children components to render where they truly are on the screen, offset is allowed to be use in subclasses. For example, PanelPlus uses a subimage which components are drawn on, and that subimage is later drawn onto the screen. Children components may need to get their true location on the screen, for use in mouse touch and clicking boundaries for example.
        Parameters:
        comp - the companion to find the render offset for
        Returns:
        a four element long pixel array for interpreting the render coordinates in terms of real locations:
        { xStart, yStart, xEnd, yEnd }
        The first two indices in the array are how far from where the component was told to render the actual render location was. Therefore, if the panel told the component to render at (0,0), but it was actually being rendered at (350,20), the first two values in the returned array would be 350 and 20 respectively.
        The third and fourth values in the returned array signify ending offsets or cut offs. If a component is told to render in the rectangle between (0,0) and (100,80), but only 40 pixels of width and 50 pixels of height are actually being drawn to the screen, then the third and fourth indices would be 40 and 50 respectively. The minimum supported cut off value would be 0 (thus having no true width/height), and negative values are to be interpreted as there being no cut off.

      • handleOffsets

        public int[][] handleOffsets​(int[] xs,
                             int[] ys,
                             MenuComponent callingComp)
        It is very frequent that components need their true coordinates for action in relation to the mouse (such as in mouse clicking or scrolling) or other uses. The coordinates that the component is told for rendering are not necessarily correct. Thus getRenderOffset(MenuComponent) can be called to get the offsets that define how far the x and y components are from their true values, and if any cutting off occurred. For single coordinate queries, it is likely easier to calculate from the render offset method, but when a larger number of points need to be handled, this method can be used.
        Parameters:
        xs - the rendering x positions
        ys - the rendering y positions
        callingComp - the component which needs its true coordinates
        Returns:
        a two dimensional array where the modified xs are in index 0, and the modified ys are in index 1. Therefore, {xs, ys}.

      • addToGrid

        public boolean addToGrid​(MenuComponent comp,
                         int x,
                         int y)
        Called by the constructor of supported MenuComponents to add the component to this panel's grid. Once the component has been added, the panel will take care of rendering and placing the component.
        Parameters:
        comp - the component to be added to this panel's grid
        x - the x position on the grid for the component
        y - the y position on the grid for the component
        Returns:
        whether the addition of the component was successful

      • removeFromGrid

        public boolean removeFromGrid​(int x,
                              int y,
                              boolean resize)
        Deletes the component found at the location (x,y) in grid.
        Parameters:
        x - the x-value of the component to remove
        y - the y-value of the component to remove
        resize - whether the grid should check for a resize after the deletion.
        Returns:
        whether a component was removed at (x,y)

      • textResize

        public boolean textResize()
        Overrides:
        textResize in class MenuComponent
        Returns:
        if text should resize by height. This is found by seeing if this panel has set a preference in textResize If a preference has been set, that is returned. Otherwise, the parent is queried to see if it has been set.

        Returns:

      • getAllHeldComponents

        public java.util.ArrayList<MenuComponent> getAllHeldComponents()
        Returns a list of all of the child components that this panel holds. By default, grid is added to the list, then comps.
        Returns:
        the array of all held menu components

      • getGridFormatter

        public GridFormatter getGridFormatter()
        Returns the formatter for this panel's grid components. Very useful to set margins, borders, or weights.
        Returns:
        the value of grid

      • removeTouchResponsiveness

        public void removeTouchResponsiveness​(MenuManager manager)
        Recursive method to remove all held components from the specified manager's list of touch responsive components. This is very useful if this panel will no longer be used or shown.
        Parameters:
        manager - the manager to remove getAllHeldComponents() from with MenuManager.removeTouchResponsiveComponent(TouchResponsiveComponent).
